etymologies: late 19th century. From German Bioblast from bio + -blast

definitions: Especially in the terminology or R. Altmann: a granule of protoplasm thought to be capable of growth and self-reproduction; a minute hypothetical primitive organism, a protobiont.

notes.text: While Altmann's ideas were oversimplified and overgeneralized, some of these visible or hypothetical ‘granules’ were later understood to be organelles, especially plastids and mitochondria.
